segments.text: I grew up in eastern Washington state, uh, uh, on the Snake river, which is, uh, a tributary of the Columbia river, in, uh, this huge, vast, sort of arid, desert part of the state.
Um, tell me about your family.
My family.
[0.80 seconds silent] My family all were kind of Dust bowl people who kind of came into that area, [0.78 seconds silent] uh, during the Depression.
And they came in lured by the, uh, work provided by the Hanford nuclear reactor.
They came from Montana, they came from North Dakota.
And, uh, because the housing shortage, they all ended up settling in this one small town.
So at one point we had, uh, generations and generations of my father's family and my mother's family [0.96 seconds silent] in this town called Burbank, Washington.
Um, it was probably [1.44 seconds silent] the most [1.36 seconds silent] happy, glorious time of my life.
You know, where you're related to half the people in the town.
Um, yeah.
I wish I had made more of it.
I wish I had talked to them more about, uh, what had brought them there.
Your relationship with your parents was good?
It was good.
You know, um, [3.42 seconds silent] it was good.
But, um.
Boy, [4.56 seconds silent] and I'm sorry, I'm one of these people that stops a lot and thinks a lot, [0.88 seconds silent] and that's really difficult for a lot of people to be with.
[0.98 seconds silent] Um, I'm not going to be a kind of wall to wall carpet of [1.12 seconds silent] talk.
Uh, that's fine.
[3.13 seconds silent] I know your father had an interesting story.
My father, uh, when he was about three years old, his father had come back from working in the shipyards in Seattle during World War II.
And the family story is that he had taken a block and tackled to the head.
He'd come back a different person.
And at one point he had flown into a rage, accusing my grandmother of adultery.
[0.92 seconds silent] And at the time, [1.07 seconds silent] uh, most of their kids were at school [0.88 seconds silent] and my father was at home.
And I believe there was another sibling at home.
My father was about three.
[1.20 seconds silent] And there was a gunshot.
And my father went around this farmhouse up in the Idaho mountains looking for his mother.
[0.88 seconds silent] And he couldn't find his mother.
And he periodically, he had to hide underneath this bed.

[1.13 seconds silent] And his father was walking around the house carrying a shotgun, [0.86 seconds silent] uh, calling for my father, um, [0.85 seconds silent] in fact, trying to find my father to kill him also.
So your grandfather suspected his wife of.

Adultery [0.88 seconds silent] and he subsequently shot her, shot the other child who was home, [0.87 seconds silent] uh, walked around the house trying to find my father to shoot him, and then ultimately shot himself.
So it was a murder suicide.
And, uh, [1.04 seconds silent] then growing up, we were always told that they had died of diphtheria.
And then around the age of 21, I was home for Christmas and my mother said, uh, [0.82 seconds silent] oh, by the way, it wasn't diphtheria.
[1.12 seconds silent] And she told me the story about the murder.
Suicide.
[1.06 seconds silent] Uh, [0.99 seconds silent] and I said, so, what bedroom?
Where were they shot?
Where were they killed?
[1.28 seconds silent] Uh, [0.79 seconds silent] and she got this funny, sad look.
And she said, do you remember that yellow bedroom that was off the kitchen?
That yellow bedroom with no windows?
[1.04 seconds silent] And I said, yeah, that was the bedroom we kids had to sleep in every summer when we went to visit.
And she said, I felt so bad turning off the light and leaving you four kids to sleep in that room every night.
[1.22 seconds silent] And, uh, it was the creepiest room.
It had no windows.
It had just a door into the kitchen.
It had a rollaway bed.
And it was that bed under which my father had hid to save his life.
And it was on that bed that my grandmother had been killed.
And then, uh, realized that for all those summers, we'd also slept on that bed.
Um, it was just a.
[0.80 seconds silent] It was a relief to hear the truth.
Um, but it was also kind of an ick moment to find out that, [1.20 seconds silent] you know, very little of that house had changed.
